title: Applied Strength and Conditioning: Content Knowledge Sequence
outcomes: Explain core physiological and programming concepts used in strength and conditioning.
Interpret assessment and training variables using evidence-based reasoning.
Defend programming decisions with clear conceptual logic and professional terminology.

resources.title: NSCA Essentials of Strength Training and Conditioning
resources.notes: Primary conceptual framework for physiology, programming variables, and periodization.

resources.title: Exercise Testing and Prescription
resources.notes: Assessment interpretation, validity, and training-response principles.

resources.title: Course Lecture Notes and Research Briefs
resources.notes: Module-specific concept explanations and applied examples.

modules.title: Module 1: Cardiorespiratory Foundations and Aerobic Adaptation Concepts
modules.competency: You will explain how aerobic physiology, VO2 concepts, and recovery kinetics inform evidence-based conditioning decisions.
modules.instruction: Read the assigned sections on oxygen transport, central/peripheral adaptation, and VO2 terminology. Focus on conceptual meaning before formulas.
modules.contentConnection: Builds the physiological vocabulary needed for all later conditioning and progression modules.
modules.learningTask: Create a concept map showing relationships among VO2max, recovery heart rate, stroke volume, and aerobic adaptation.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 500-700 word explanatory brief that interprets aerobic assessment outputs and explains how they guide initial intensity and progression decisions.

masteryCheck.prompt: How do VO2-related indicators and recovery trends together improve the quality of aerobic programming decisions?

modules.title: Module 2: Strength Assessment Logic and Load Prescription Theory
modules.competency: You will explain the conceptual basis for submaximal testing, 1RM estimation, and intensity-zone selection.
modules.instruction: Study motor unit recruitment, rate coding, and the logic of submaximal prediction equations. Emphasize why these models are used.
modules.contentConnection: Extends Module 1 measurement logic into neuromuscular assessment and load prescription.
modules.learningTask: Compare two prediction equations and produce a short analysis of what each model assumes about fatigue and repetition performance.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 500-700 word rationale explaining why specific %1RM ranges align with different adaptation goals in novice populations.

masteryCheck.prompt: Why is moderate-to-high relative intensity commonly recommended for foundational strength adaptation in novices?

modules.title: Module 3: Movement Pattern Theory and Structural Balance
modules.competency: You will explain how movement classification and structural balance principles support safe, effective long-term development.
modules.instruction: Review movement pattern categories and agonist/antagonist relationships. Focus on conceptual signs of imbalance and compensation.
modules.contentConnection: Connects neuromuscular concepts to movement-system thinking and injury-risk reduction principles.
modules.learningTask: Develop an annotated framework that defines each major movement pattern and explains its role in balanced programming.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 450-650 word analysis defending structural balance priorities using biomechanical and adaptation-focused reasoning.

masteryCheck.prompt: How does structural imbalance increase injury risk over time, and why does push-pull balance matter conceptually?

modules.title: Module 4: Volume, Intensity, and Overload Concepts
modules.competency: You will explain how volume, intensity, rest, and frequency interact to drive distinct neuromuscular adaptations.
modules.instruction: Read NSCA guidance on training variables and overload models. Pay attention to the conceptual difference between stress dose and adaptation outcome.
modules.contentConnection: Builds from Module 2 by shifting from single-variable decisions to multivariable adaptation planning.
modules.learningTask: Create a comparison chart of linear, double, and undulating progression models with strengths, limits, and best-use contexts.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 600-800 word explanatory essay describing how variable manipulation changes adaptation direction in novice clients.

masteryCheck.prompt: How do volume and intensity create different adaptation signals, and why must they be balanced over time?

modules.title: Module 5: Energy Systems and Concurrent Training Concepts
modules.competency: You will explain oxidative, glycolytic, and phosphagen system demands and the conceptual basis of the interference effect.
modules.instruction: Study energy system characteristics and concurrent training literature. Focus on mechanism-level explanations rather than session planning.
modules.contentConnection: Integrates cardiorespiratory and resistance concepts into a unified adaptation framework.
modules.learningTask: Construct a concept matrix linking training stimulus type to dominant energy system demand and expected adaptation outcomes.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 550-750 word explanation of the interference effect and defend two evidence-based strategies that reduce its impact.

masteryCheck.prompt: What is the interference effect, and which programming principles reduce it without removing conditioning work?

modules.title: Module 6: Fatigue Monitoring and Autoregulation Theory
modules.competency: You will explain fatigue typology, performance trend interpretation, and autoregulatory decision logic.
modules.instruction: Review central/peripheral fatigue concepts, overreaching definitions, and RPE-based autoregulation frameworks.
modules.contentConnection: Moves from fixed planning logic to responsive decision-making based on adaptation signals.
modules.learningTask: Analyze three written case scenarios and identify which fatigue pattern is present and what conceptual adjustment rule applies.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 500-700 word decision framework that explains when and why load, volume, or frequency should be adjusted.

masteryCheck.prompt: How do you distinguish functional overreaching from non-functional overreaching using trend-based evidence?

modules.title: Module 7: Coaching Communication and Motivation Concepts
modules.competency: You will explain how autonomy support, feedback quality, and communication structure influence adherence and performance.
modules.instruction: Read assigned material on motivation theory, coaching language, and feedback timing. Focus on psychological mechanisms and behavior change principles.
modules.contentConnection: Adds behavior and communication science to technical programming knowledge.
modules.learningTask: Develop a concept brief that contrasts autonomy-supportive versus controlling coaching language and predicted client responses.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 450-650 word reflection analyzing how communication choices alter competence perception, engagement, and long-term adherence.

masteryCheck.prompt: Why does autonomy-supportive coaching typically improve adherence and perceived competence?

modules.title: Module 8: Periodization and Macrocycle Knowledge Synthesis
modules.competency: You will synthesize assessment, adaptation, progression, and recovery concepts into a coherent periodization rationale.
modules.instruction: Review macrocycle and mesocycle theory, deload logic, and progression architecture. Emphasize conceptual coherence and evidence alignment.
modules.contentConnection: Synthesizes all previous modules into an integrated knowledge framework for long-term program reasoning.
modules.learningTask: Create an annotated concept outline showing how assessment data, overload progression, conditioning integration, and monitoring connect across an 8-week plan.
modules.applicationTask: Write a 700-900 word capstone defense explaining the logic of an 8-week periodized model and how each phase supports targeted adaptation.

masteryCheck.prompt: How should assessment evidence shape macrocycle structure and progression decisions across phases?
